Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for only 173 days, falling short of the 1,095-day requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Lived and worked in Mexico during the required residency period
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet physical presence requirement for citizenship
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of physical presence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of Citizenship Judge’s decision and grant of citizenship
Governing_Rule: Re Pourghasemi – 1,095 days of physical presence required
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence documented
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Harm_Assessment: No harm from legal error; law correctly applied
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement due to residing in Mexico
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed and accepted official records of entry and stay
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant did not provide evidence to meet the residency burden
Decision_Rationale: Judge correctly applied Re Pourghasemi and provided adequate reasons
Country_of_Origin: Mexico (location of residence during relevant period)
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of sufficient documentation proving physical presence
